stories.title: Workout.cool – Open-source fitness coaching platform
stories.author: surgomat
stories.article_summary: The article introduces **workout.cool**, a modern open-source fitness coaching platform designed to create and track workout plans while accessing a detailed exercise database. The project was initiated by the original contributor of **workout.lol**, who aimed to address the challenges faced by the previous platform, particularly issues with exercise video partnerships that led to its abandonment. The new platform supports **Node.js 18+** and can be deployed via **Docker** or a manual **PostgreSQL** setup, with installation commands like `pnpm install` and `make init` for ease of use. Future enhancements include a mobile app, gamification features, and integration with wearables, emphasizing a community-driven approach to revitalize fitness tools. The contributor emphasizes, "This isn't just a revival; it's an evolution," inviting developers and fitness enthusiasts to engage with the project through contributions and suggestions.

comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion highlights the challenges faced by the original contributor of workout.lol, including the lack of communication from the new owner after the sale and the abandonment of the project despite its initial success. The contributor's repeated attempts to engage with the new owner over 9 months resulted in no responses, leading to frustration and the decision to consider rebuilding the project from scratch due to licensing issues.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter highlights their experience with workout.lol, an open-source fitness app that gained popularity but was ultimately abandoned after being sold, leading to frustration as they attempted to revive it through persistent outreach, illustrating the challenges of maintaining community-driven projects post-acquisition.

failed_attempts: Repo went abandoned after new owner stopped maintaining it
15 emails sent to new owner with no replies

top_comments.author: surgomat
top_comments.text:
I was the main contributor to workout.lol, an open-source fitness app to easily build a workout routine.
The project had traction (1.4k GitHub stars, 95 forks, ~20K visits/month), but was eventually sold due to video licensing hurdles. The new owner stopped maintaining it, and the repo went abandoned.
Over the next 9 months, I sent 15 emails to try to save it : no replies. Feature requests & issues were ignored. The community was left with a "broken" tool let's say.
I couldn't just let it die So I built the new version from scratch with the same open-source spirit, but a better architecture long-term vision, more features and no license problems.
It's called : Workout.cool (https://workout.cool)
What it offers:
100% open-source, MIT-licensed
1200+ exercises (with videos, attributes, translations)
Progress tracking
Multilingual-ready
Self-hostable
I'm not doing this for money. I'm doing it because I believe in open fitness tools, and I’ve been passionate about strength training for 15+ years.
If this resonates with you, feel free to:
- Star the repo
- Share with fitness/tech friends
- Suggest features
- Contribute code/design/docs
Together, we can build the open-source fitness platform we all wanted to easily build a workout routine and get in shape
Website: https://workout.cool GitHub: https://github.com/Snouzy/workout-cool

top_comments.author: KPGv2
top_comments.text: Open source just means the source code is available. It doesn't mean you can legally use it. That is, in fact, the whole point behind the most famous open source license, GPLv3: code is open source, but there are still restrictions on how you can use the code. I don't know about now (most projects I work on are MIT-licensed, these days), but there was rancor around the move from v2 to v3 because v3 was more restrictive.

top_comments.author: bramhaag
top_comments.text:
'source available' means the source code is available. Open source comes with a whole set of guarantees [1] about free redistribution and derived works.
Copyleft licenses like the GPL come with extra guarantees that do not violate the core guarantees of open source software. Instead, they make them stronger. The 'restrictions' GPL imposes essentially boil down to this: "if you use (parts of) GPL software, you must give your users the same freedoms the GPL guarantees." GPLv3 and AGPL closed up loopholes that allowed people to bypass those clauses.
[1] https://opensource.org/osd

top_comments.author: thayne
top_comments.text:
Even if it was licensed under GPL, which it isn't, forking the project to create another open source project is allowed, as long as the fork is also GPL licensed.
But in this case the original project used the MIT license, so the only requirement is that it the form includes attribution to the original project.

stories.title: Homomorphically Encrypting CRDTs
stories.author: jakelazaroff
stories.article_summary: The article discusses the integration of homomorphic encryption with Conflict-free Replicated Data Types (CRDTs) to enable secure, collaborative document editing in local-first software. It highlights the challenge of sharing sensitive documents without exposing their contents to sync servers, proposing homomorphic encryption as a solution. Using the TFHE-rs library, a Rust implementation, the author demonstrates a basic example of adding two encrypted integers, showcasing that operations on encrypted data yield results identical to those performed on plaintext. The article emphasizes that while homomorphic encryption allows computations on encrypted data, it remains computationally intensive, limiting its current practical applications. Key insights include the potential for enhanced privacy in collaborative applications and the need for further optimization in homomorphic encryption to achieve usability in production environments.

agreement_points: FHE is a relatively new field
disagreement_points: Is the CRDT slow or the server's role?

comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion highlights the complexities and challenges associated with CRDTs and fully homomorphic encryption. While CRDTs are recognized for their slow performance due to architectural decisions, the community acknowledges the advancements in FHE since its inception in 2009. There is a debate about the efficiency of CRDTs when combined with FHE, with some questioning whether the slowness is inherent to the CRDTs themselves or the server's role in the architecture.

top_comments.author: plopilop
top_comments.text:
As the article mentions, fully homomorphic encryption is insanely slow and inefficient. But I have to say that it is a relatively new field (the first FHE scheme was discovered in 2009), and that the field has immensely progressed over the last decade and a half.
The first FHE scheme required keys of several TB/PB, bootstrapping (an operation that is pivotal in FHE schemes, when too many multiplications are computed) would take thousands of hours. We are now down to keys of "only" 30 MB, and bootstrapping in less than 0.1 second.
Hopefully progress will continue and FHE will become more practical.

stories.title: "poline" is an enigmatic color palette generator using polar coordinates
stories.author: zdw
stories.article_summary: "Poline" is a TypeScript micro-library designed for generating color palettes by drawing lines between anchor points, represented as HSL values. Users can create palettes with a minimum of two anchors, and the richness of colors increases with the number of points defined—defaulting to four but adjustable via the 'numPoints' property. The library offers various position functions, including linear and sinusoidal, to control color distribution, and features like hue shifting and the ability to close loops for seamless palettes. "Poline" is available as an npm package and can be imported directly from a CDN, making it easily accessible for developers looking to enhance their design projects.

comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion reflects mixed sentiments towards the poline color palette generator, with some users appreciating its uniqueness while others criticize the palettes as unattractive or not very useful. stories.title: Is There a Half-Life for the Success Rates of AI Agents?
stories.author: EvgeniyZh
stories.article_summary: In the article "Is there a Half-Life for the Success Rates of AI Agents?" by Toby Ord, it is revealed that AI agents exhibit an exponentially declining success rate as task duration increases, modeled by a constant failure rate per minute. Citing Kwa et al. (2025) from METR, the article notes that the task length AI can handle doubles every 7 months, based on a suite of 170 tasks, with a 50% success rate achievable for tasks up to 59 minutes but only 15 minutes for an 80% success rate. The findings suggest that each agent has a "half-life" defined by the time it takes a human to complete tasks, highlighting a critical insight: "the task length for an 80% success rate is 1/4 the task length for a 50% success rate." This model invites further exploration of AI capabilities across diverse tasks, while acknowledging limitations in generalizability.

comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion highlights challenges with context management in LLMs, particularly the phenomenon of context rot that diminishes output quality after around 100k tokens. Users share experiences of switching libraries and clearing context to improve performance. There is a consensus on the need for better context management tools, with specific mentions of features in Claude Code and LM Studio that allow users to clear or compact context effectively.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter shares their experience with an LLM that repeatedly switched libraries in an attempt to resolve build errors, highlighting that prolonged attempts often yield unsatisfactory results. They suggest that if an issue isn't resolved quickly, the model tends to struggle further.

working_setups: Starting a new session with previous context helps steer LLM

actionable_advice: Use context clearing tools to manage output quality
Start new sessions when LLM goes off track

top_comments.author: mikeocool
top_comments.text:
This very much aligns with my experience — I had a case yesterday where opus was trying to do something with a library, and it encountered a build error. Rather than fix the error, it decided to switch to another library. It then encountered another error and decided to switch back to the first library.
I don’t think I’ve encountered a case where I’ve just let the LLM churn for more than a few minutes and gotten a good result. If it doesn’t solve an issue on the first or second pass, it seems to rapidly start making things up, make totally unrelated changes claiming they’ll fix the issue, or trying the same thing over and over.

top_comments.author: Workaccount2
top_comments.text:
They poison their own context. Maybe you can call it context rot, where as context grows and especially if it grows with lots of distractions and dead ends, the output quality falls off rapidly. Even with good context the rot will start to become apparent around 100k tokens (with Gemini 2.5).
They really need to figure out a way to delete or "forget" prior context, so the user or even the model can go back and prune poisonous tokens.
Right now I work around it by regularly making summaries of instances, and then spinning up a new instance with fresh context and feed in the summary of the previous instance.

top_comments.author: steveklabnik
top_comments.text:
> They really need to figure out a way to delete or "forget" prior context, so the user or even the model can go back and prune poisonous tokens.
In Claude Code you can use /clear to clear context, or /compact <optional message> to compact it down, with the message guiding what stays and what goes. It's helpful.

top_comments.author: OtherShrezzing
top_comments.text:
>They really need to figure out a way to delete or "forget" prior context, so the user or even the model can go back and prune poisonous tokens.
This is possible in tools like LM Studio when running LLMs locally. It's a choice by the implementer to grant this ability to end users. You pass the entire context to the model in each turn of the conversation, so there's no technical reason stopping this feature existing, besides maybe some cost benefits to the inference vendor from cache.

top_comments.author: codeflo
top_comments.text:
I wonder to what extent this might be a case where the base model (the pure token prediction model without RLHF) is "taking over". This is a bit tongue-in-cheek, but if you see a chat protocol where an assistant makes 15 random wrong suggestions, the most likely continuation has to be yet another wrong suggestion.
People have also been reporting that ChatGPT's new "memory" feature is poisoning their context. But context is also useful. I think AI companies will have to put a lot of engineering effort into keeping those LLMs on the happy path even with larger and larger contexts.

top_comments.author: kossae
top_comments.text: This is my experience as well, and for now comes down to a workflow optimization. As I feel the LLM getting off track, I start a brand new session with useful previous context pasted in from my previous session. This seems to help steer it back to a decent solution, but agreed it would be nice if this was more automated based off of user/automated feedback (broken unit test, "this doesn't work", etc.)
